title: HClO4 and KClO4 buffer - chlorite ion structure

content.question: Consider the Lewis electron-dot diagram for the <math alttext="C l O 2 with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ion that minimizes formal charge. Which of the following is true about the hybridization of the <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom in the ion?

choices.label: The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is not hybridized, and the ion contains one single <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond and one double <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond.

The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is <math alttext="s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hybridized, and the ion contains two equivalent <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> double bonds.

The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is <math alttext="s p 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> hybridized, and the ion contains two equivalent <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> single bonds.

The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is <math alttext="s p 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> hybridized, and the ion contains two equivalent <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> single bonds.

content.answer: The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is <math alttext="s p 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> hybridized, and the ion contains two equivalent <math alttext="C l O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> single bonds.
